{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19833,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rhinotropis californica, also known as the California Milkwort, prefers well-draining soil and does not require frequent watering once established. During its growing season, moderate watering is ideal, allowing the soil to slightly dry out between watering sessions. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it is crucial to avoid waterlogging the soil. In the dormant period, typically during the colder months, reduce the watering frequency significantly to prevent excess moisture. One way to ensure proper hydration is to water deeply but infrequently, allowing the natural environment to guide the plant's watering needs."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rhinotropis californica thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth. This helps to promote vigorous blooming and healthy foliage. If grown indoors, place the plant near a south or west-facing window where it can receive ample light. In environments where full sun is not consistently available, partial shading during the harshest mid-day sun can help protect the plant, but it is important to ensure that it still receives a majority of its light requirements. Insufficient sunlight may lead to sparse blooming and leggy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rhinotropis californica generally involves the removal of dead, damaged, or diseased stems to encourage healthy growth. Regular pruning can also help in maintaining the shape and size of this plant. It is best to prune soon after flowering to avoid cutting down buds for the next blooming season. Use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts, ensuring not to leave any jagged edges that could invite pests or diseases. Additionally, light trimming can be done during its growing season to encourage a fuller plant, but avoid excessive cutting as this can stress the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"California milkwort","description":"Rhinotropis californica, synonym Polygala californica, is a species of flowering plant in the milkwort family known by the common name California milkwort. It is native to southwestern Oregon and northern and central California, where it grows in the coastal mountain ranges in local habitat types such as chaparral and forest. It is a perennial herb producing spreading stems, generally decumbent in form, up to about 35 centimeters in maximum length, lined with narrow oval leaves each...","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["California","Baja California"],"other_name":["California milkwort"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Rhinotropis californica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Dry"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19639,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hypericum kalmianum, commonly known as Kalm's St. John's Wort, prefers moderate, consistent watering. It thrives in well-drained soil and does not tolerate waterlogged conditions, which can lead to root rot. During the growing season, aim to keep the soil consistently moist but not saturated. In periods of drought or extreme heat, increase watering frequency. However, in cooler months, reduce the amount of water to prevent overwatering. Mulching around the base can help retain moisture and regulate soil temperature, making it particularly beneficial in maintaining a healthy watering regimen."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Kalm's St. John's Wort thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal flower production and healthy growth, aim to provide at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. While it can tolerate partial shade, too little light may lead to reduced flowering and a leggy or sparse appearance. In areas with intense afternoon sun, providing some shade can protect the plant from heat stress. It is adaptable to different conditions but ensuring adequate sunlight will support vibrant blooms and robust foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Kalm's St. John's Wort is generally straightforward and should be done in early spring before new growth starts. To maintain a bushy, healthy shape, remove any dead or damaged branches. Lightly trimming can help in encouraging fresh growth and enhancing flowering throughout the growing season. It's also important to prune spent flowers to prevent the plant from becoming leggy and to promote a prolonged blooming period. Avoid heavy pruning as it can stress the plant and reduce flowering potential in the upcoming season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Kalm's St. John's-wort","description":"Hypericum kalmianum, commonly called Kalm's St. Johns wort or Kalm's St. Johnswort, is a small, yellow-flowering shrub native to the Great Lakes region in the northern United States and southern Canada. It is in the St. John's wort family, Hypericaceae. Hypericum kalmianum was named after its discoverer, Swedish botanist Pehr Kalm (1715-1779).","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Kalm's St. John's-wort"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Rust"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Hypericum kalmianum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

These orchids should be watered regularly to keep the soil evenly moist, especially during their active growing season in the cooler months. However, it's important to ensure that the roots do not sit in water, so good drainage is essential. During the dormancy period in the warmer months, reduce watering significantly, allowing the soil to dry out slightly between watering sessions, simulating their natural habitat conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pterostylis melagramma orchids thrive in partial to full shade, mimicking their natural woodland understory habitats. They prefer indirect light or dappled sunlight, making them ideal for growing under trees or in shaded garden areas. Direct sunlight, especially during the hotter parts of the day, can damage their foliage and impede growth. Therefore, it is important to provide them with protection from harsh sunlight while ensuring they receive enough light to promote flowering during their active growing periods."},{"type":"pruning","description":"The pruning of Pterostylis melagramma mainly involves removing dead or yellowing leaves as they appear. This helps prevent any potential disease and encourages healthy growth. Additionally, after the orchid has finished flowering, you can carefully cut back the spent flower stems to tidy the plant and redirect energy back into the tubers for next season's growth. Regular inspection of the plant for pests or signs of disease is also a recommended part of pruning care."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"tall greenhood","description":"Pterostylis melagramma, commonly known as the black-stripe leafy greenhood is a plant in the orchid family Orchidaceae and is endemic to south-eastern Australia.
